title: I fully support the damage paths Yasuo can run with.
body: What I don't agree with at all are the fervor abuse tank/bruiser yasuo builds. Winning by virtue of stacking fervor and being tankier is not how he's supposed to be played, I want to see the glass cannon yasuo builds again.

replies.body: Riot says they think it's a problem too. How exactly they intend to address that problem is a mystery to me. I really don't know how you can nerf bruiser Yasuo without nerfing carry Yasuo even harder.
Probably lowering base damage on his abilities and reducing his passive crit penalty, making him want to build at least 2 items for his 100% crit.

The only problem with that is that it makes his early game even weaker, which could easily make him unplayable in many matchups. There's a limit to just how weak Yasuo can be early game given his lack of an escape, disengage, and ranged farming.

You don't play Yasuo much do you?
Isn't the suggestion to nerf his early base? wouldnt that slow his pushing power so he shoots himself in the foot less?

Nerfing his early base is a bad idea, he is only shooting himself in the foot is he's a bad player or doesn't know Yasuo well, as a smart Yasuo can stack Q by last hitting when necessary, he will push lane which means you can easily gank him, but you can freeze the lane if you are smart enough not to randomly Q and E. His early game is weak because of this pushing power, so nerfing his early game will just make him even worse because his base damage will be lower but he's still gonna be pushing and will have an even harder time playing safe. Yasuo's pretty much designed to be aggressive and push, your supposed to play like that, its a risk for reward playstyle but nerfing him will only reduce the reward. Sorry if this all seems like rambling, hard to explain. What needs to be nerfed are the items he uses, I fully agree with a PD nerf as that's his main power in the top lane bruiser build.

4.Yasuo's pretty much designed to be aggressive and push, your supposed to play like that

So are you supposed to push or not? you say his early game is weak because he pushes, but he's supposed to push, but you can control your push if you're not bad, but somehow if you do less damage and control your push you push harder and are more likely to play unsafely? which is it man?

let me show you the proper flow chart; do less damage -> push and manage wave deliberately with less accidental shove -> shove wave when intentional because it's what you're supposed to do.

 play safe when you want to and shove when you want to. thats how it works. doing less damage doesnt ever translate into shove lane harder. ever.

His early game is weak because of his pushing power as it makes him very vulnerable to ganks, and he doesn't have the capability to prevent them or get out with any sense of ease. He will always push, but a good Yasuo will do it slower and try to keep it from spiraling out of control. If he does less damage, his kit still requires him to push the lane to utilize it, only he has less damage to out play ganks or 1v1 the opponent. You are supposed to push as Yasuo, but the difference between a good Yasuo and a bad one is how hard you push. Your kit requires you to, but it doesn't make you constantly Q and E the wave just to get stacks, if you are smart you'll use it when you need in. Its still gonna push but it will be slower. Yasuo doing less damage isn't gonna make him stop pushing, he needs to push to get the most out of his kit, doing less damage means he has even less safety while doing it.

His early game is weak because his base damage are piss poor and he's squishy. He early game is NOT weak because of his pushing power; pushing power is pretty much always a strength early game since you can choose to not utilize it. You think Renekton and Darius are so strong early game just because? No. They're so strong early game because they outtrade their opponents AND push to gain an even greater advantage. Yasuo, on the other hand, pretty much **needs** to push if he wants to be aggressive, but he doesn't **have** to be aggressive. Just hanging back and CSing with Q is 100% an option. A pretty boring option, mind you, but a valid one.

I think you'll find that, assuming equal health, E-W-AA-Q will win you most trades against most champs from lvl 3 onward. Before that? Pretty weak. That's why I explained it the way I did. Talon doesn't have a weak early game. He has a weak lvls 1 and 2. But once he's lvl 3? All bets are off.

E-W-AA-Q nets talon 228 damage against the target at level three 

brand's combo with two AAs at the same level is 365 damage plus 12% of the target's max health 

leblanc deals 395 damage with the same set up 

karthus has him beat, assuming this trade took 2 seconds, with 340 damage.

zed gets 302 damage off in this trade 

yasuo is pretty much only champion who commonly goes midlane and would lose to talon in this trade.

most of talon's damage is from bonus AD ratios and his ult; it's why tank talon was never a thing even when tank assassins were in their prime.
Levels 1 through 5 he has neither bonus AD nor his ult and is a sitting duck.

Your math seems awful. A typical talon, at minimum, will have 79 AD at lvl 3, assuming he started corrupting pot. W will do 78 damage. The first auto will do 79 damage. The Q auto will do 138 damage. All told, that's 295 damage. But wait, you have to account for the damage amp from his passive and his E as well. So tack on another 13% damage= 333 damage. But wait, Talon also has thunderlords, and that damage is also increased by those modifiers, so add another 50 magic damage. So you do 383 damage with that combo, and that's without accounting for any damage that corrupting pot may do. Those numbers go even higher if Talon started an AD item instead of Corrupting pot. 

So yeah, Talon can most certainly compete with other champs at lvl 3.
